meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>axe</radical> is sticking in the <radical>ground</radical> on top of a <radical>mountain</radical>. It's sticking into the very <kanji>peak</kanji>. Because why would you bother to stick your axe anywhere else on the mountain to prove you climbed it?
reading_mnemonic: You can't help but <reading>gawk</reading> (がく) at the <kanji>peak</kanji>. Somehow it looks even higher now.

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>tsunami</radical> struck, it hit your <radical>tent</radical> full of <radical>beans</radical>. When you lost your tent of beans, you had a moment of <kanji>lucidity</kanji>. You don't need so much stuff, you can live without it!
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>lucidity</kanji> is clear to everyone because you wear a <reading>su</reading>it (す). Everyone knows that lucid people wear suits!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>spear</radical> radical and the <kanji>spear</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: You take this <kanji>spear</kanji> and stab it into a cow. "<reading>MOO</reading> (む)!" it cries. The cow bites the spear out of your hands and stabs you back. "MOO!" you scream.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> <radical>table</radical> is a table that's made entirely of <kanji>skin</kanji>. You thought the table was made of moon, with all those pores and such, but when you look more closely, you realize it's skin. Disgusting, porous, skin.
reading_mnemonic: But, when you go to touch this "moon table" made of <kanji>skin</kanji>, you realize that it's <reading>harder</reading> (はだ) than you expected.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>boat</radical> radical and the <kanji>boat</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same reading that you learned with the vocabulary 船.

meaning_mnemonic: Something made of <radical>gold</radical> <radical>stand</radical>s in a <radical>village</radical>. It's a <kanji>bell</kanji>!  The village bell.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>bell</kanji> rings whenever the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) arrives in the village. Its ringing echoes throughout the entire village so everyone knows they have to come out and pay their respects.

meaning_mnemonic: If there's a <radical>treasure chest</radical>, there's always a <kanji>villain</kanji> too. The villain is trying to get to the treasure chest before the hero of the story.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>villain</kanji> beat you all the way to <reading>きょう</reading>と to get this particular treasure chest.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>dirt</radical> <radical>demon</radical> is just a <kanji>lump</kanji>. Just like a dust bunny is just a clump of dust.
reading_mnemonic: A <kanji>lump</kanji> of something is just a <reading>固まり</reading> (かたまり) — the hardened thing itself.

meaning_mnemonic: I <radical>protect</radical> my own <radical>animal</radical>s by going to <kanji>hunt</kanji> other animals... like wolves and cougars and such.
reading_mnemonic: I also do all my <kanji>hunt</kanji>s using a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). I just run those animals down with my car. Kind of cheating, but vroom vroom anyways.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>spoon</radical> to measure a <radical>geoduck</radical> is a very <kanji>approximate</kanji> measurement. Geoducks are big, spoons are small. Still, we'll get the approximation going, right?
reading_mnemonic: Maybe this is too much geoduck, even if we're going for an <kanji>approximate</kanji>. So, you take the <reading>core</reading> (ころ) of the geoduck and measure that instead.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>cloud</radical> floating above a <radical>demon</radical> has its <kanji>soul</kanji> in it. If you can manage to get through to the demon, to make it see that it doesn't have to be evil, it might remember who it is and return to the <kanji>spirit</kanji> it once was.
reading_mnemonic: You shout out and beg its <kanji>soul</kanji> for help until, finally, you see the cloud take the shape of a <reading>con</reading>dor (こん). Aha! "You were a condor before you became a demon! Remember who you are and turn back!"

meaning_mnemonic: If you've been to the <radical>moon</radical> in the <radical>past</radical>, you had to get the special <radical>stamp</radical> on your <kanji>leg</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You've only met one other person with the same mark on their <kanji>leg</kanji> and it was <reading>Kyaku</reading> (きゃく) the customer. Kyaku visits many places all over the world, so it only makes sense that they've also been off-world too.

meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>alligator</radical> is <kanji>considerably</kanji> dangerous. Considerably terrifying too. Considerably [put your scary adjective here].
reading_mnemonic: Speaking of <kanji>considerably</kanji> terrifying, that place known as <reading>Nar</reading>nia (なり) is pretty terrifying. Not sure why children want to go there.

meaning_mnemonic: From the <radical>mouth</radical> of your <radical>older brother</radical> comes... a <kanji>curse</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Turns out, he put the <reading>no ro</reading>ad (のろ) curse on you, meaning you can never walk on roads.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> who is a <radical>nurse</radical> should be called <kanji>miss</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: "Call me <kanji>Miss</kanji> <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう)," Joe says to you.

meaning_mnemonic: Looking up to the <radical>cliff</radical>, you see the <radical>tree</radical>s, and the <radical>sun</radical> shining down on them. Using the sun and the trees (up there on the cliff), you've devised a method to tell what time of the year it is, based on where the shadow from the trees fall. After a while, you develop a bigger system. This system is a whole <kanji>calendar</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Remember the word 歴史, which means "history"? Using a <kanji>calendar</kanji>, you too can remember history (otherwise, who knows when these things happened). So, the reading for this kanji is the same as the reading for 歴史's beginning, because they're related.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is being blocked by a <radical>rain</radical> <radical>cloud</radical>, making it <kanji>cloudy</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Remember 雲? It means "cloud" and has the same reading as "cloudy," making them both <reading>くも</reading>.

meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>eye</radical> catches an <radical>omen</radical>, it's only natural that you will <kanji>stare</kanji> at it.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>stare</kanji> at the omen, you see Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう) knocking down buildings, putting nails on the street, and making herself way longer than you ever thought possible. Oh, and there she is, destroying the world.

meaning_mnemonic: If you're showing me your "<radical>spirit</radical> <radical>fruit</radical>" then you are just <kanji>naked</kanji>. You're <kanji>nude</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Known for being <kanji>naked</kanji> (and showing you his spirit fruit) is the ancient Egyptian god <reading>Ra</reading> (ら).

meaning_mnemonic: I'm putting all my <radical>shellfish</radical> on <radical>someone</radical>, hoping they'll win the race! This is a <kanji>gamble</kanji> and you're gambling.
reading_mnemonic: If you win this <kanji>gamble</kanji> you'll have enough shellfish to buy a brand new <reading>ca</reading>r (か)!

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>receive</radical> instruction in a <radical>circle</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical>. Where are you? <kanji>Cram school</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Not only does your <kanji>cram school</kanji> teach kids in a circle in the dirt, it also plays music on a <reading>juke</reading>box (じゅく). Yes, a jukebox. They believe a jukebox's tunes help with cramming.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>toe</radical> is <radical>early</radical>. I hate it when the toes show up early. Well, if the toes are going to show up this early, I guess it's best to put them on the <kanji>table</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: What do all the early toes on the <kanji>table</kanji> do while they're waiting until it's the right time? They just sit around on their table, <reading>talk</reading>ing (たく).

meaning_mnemonic: Below this <radical>canopy</radical> of <radical>tree</radical>s is a <radical>stone</radical>. Since it's the only stone here, you make sure to <kanji>polish</kanji> it.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>polish</kanji> the stone due to your <reading>meager</reading> (みが) lifestyle.

meaning_mnemonic: When you leave <radical>grain</radical>s in your <radical>mouth</radical> for long enough, they'll turn into <radical>flowers</radical> of <kanji>bacteria</kanji>. These aren't the nice, pretty flowers you'd give your mom on Mother's Day. These are little bacteria flowers that are taking over your mouth. Maybe brush your teeth next time.
reading_mnemonic: There is a lot of this <kanji>bacteria</kanji> in the <reading>Kin</reading>g (きん) of England's mouth. He eats a lot of grains, and he won't let anyone touch his mouth to clean it, but he refuses to do things himself... so it's absolutely chock full of bacteria.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> <radical>now</radical> has a <radical>cloud</radical> over it, creating <kanji>shade</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The building that's getting this nice <kanji>shade</kanji> is the <reading>inn</reading> (いん) you're staying at.

meaning_mnemonic: Coming down with the <radical>rain</radical> is <radical>two</radical> <radical>spikes</radical>. They go right through two <kanji>ghost</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: You come across the <kanji>ghost</kanji>s, who are stabbed into the ground. "Please," they beg. "Please use that <reading>ray</reading> (れい) gun that's in that <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat and end our suffering."

meaning_mnemonic: After the <radical>tsunami</radical> the <radical>sun</radical> comes out again and shines on these <radical>spikes</radical>. They were super wet before, but you figure the sun probably dried them off. You lean down to touch them and nope, they's still <kanji>damp</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: As you're looking at the <kanji>damp</kanji> spikes, a <reading>shih tzu</reading> (しつ) prances over, slips on the damp ground, and falls right on the spike! Oh nooo!

meaning_mnemonic: You feel like a <radical>stone</radical> that’s been <radical>renew</radical>ed. How do renewed stones feel? <kanji>Stiff</kanji>. Very stiff.
reading_mnemonic: You remember how you used to cure these <kanji>stiff</kanji> body times: your old friend <reading>こう</reading>いち would just massage them out for you.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>grain</radical>s you have stored in your <radical>house</radical> reflect on your <kanji>earnings</kanji>. If you earn a lot of money, you have more grains.
reading_mnemonic: Another way to check someone's <kanji>earnings</kanji> is to see if they have a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). Would someone who doesn't make a lot of money have a car? No!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>woman</radical> who makes your <radical>house</radical> a home is your <kanji>bride</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Now that you have a <kanji>bride</kanji> in your house, you can get rid of <reading>yo</reading>ur <reading>mai</reading>d (よめ), since your bride will do all the cleaning.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Tsunami</radical> vs <radical>lifeguard</radical>. Who will win? After the water drains away, we find the lifeguard in the <kanji>gutter</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: In the <kanji>gutter</kanji> is a lifeguard, so Emperor <reading>こう</reading>いち decides to survey the damage.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> in the shape of a <radical>dragon</radical> flies off the cliff, then comes crashing down to the ground. This skinny tsunami of water flying down to the ground is a <kanji>waterfall</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Despite how cool a dragon <kanji>waterfall</kanji> is, to be honest it's also pretty <reading>tacky</reading> (たき).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>animal</radical> <radical>king</radical>? He's just this guy who lives in the forest and thinks he's king of all the animals. He's a <kanji>lunatic</kanji>, though.
reading_mnemonic: You might see that <kanji>crazy</kanji> <kanji>lunatic</kanji> hanging around the outskirts of <reading>きょう</reading>と. He'll lurk near your trash cans and scream, "I AM THE ANIMAL KING!" and run away with some orange peels.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sheep</radical> with <radical>feathers</radical> (and presumably wings, too) is able to <kanji>fly</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Watching that sheep with feathers and wings flying around made you thirsty. You remember that you have a <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>ke</reading>ttle (かけ), so you reach into your car and grab your car kettle to make a special car-kettle brew.
